title: Wednesday, 28th February, 2018

That's on the expectation that a lot of Toys 'R' Us tat will be sold off by the administrator, of course.

red anything apart from too cheap to send and non-disc u feel.

hmm

11:09 am

Paper Chase @Bonnemort Maplin was always Maplin. @Electric Dragon yes, I used to spend many, many hours poring over the catalogue late eighties / early nineties. Happy times.

Bonnemort (x was a typo not a kiss btw)

"strategic refresh"

11:15 am

red a lot of these huge stores can be converted to online warehouses.

That's the one. Which means more cash on doing stuff like making programmes.

red @Mr Diamondthis. hence dead in water
erlkin can we talk a little macro ....? or how is justeat trading ? lol

Second, the Q1 advertising scores don't look anywhere close to expectations.

FATDAZ @grouchmonkey UBS have a note on them today but sadly not seen it here is a headline ITV plc "FY17 Group EBITA in line, but guidance is for higher costs. Special dividend cut."Positives: pension deficit, studios organic revenue growth. Negatives: higher cost guidance, end to special dividend, higher net debt. Q118 TV NAR guided +1%.
11:17 am
BE11:17am

Which had moved higher in recent weeks after the likes of Interpublic and Publicis went for a return to organic growth in 2018.

Grouchmonkey \2fatDaz thanks. UBS's conclusion?
FATDAZ @red are we 100% certain it will be Weidman it should be but
BE11:18am

And started talking about the FMCG companies spending properly again, now that 3G's not going to buy them all (at least in the very short term).

Flaneur I wonder if there is much movement in the pension/property market - more precisely the personally held and managed SIPP market. Lots of movement in and out of tax wrappers flatter the health and condition of the SME property market. I imagine many, many landlords hanging on by fingertips, off loading comm props at 0 rents just to cover tax liabilities.
BE11:19am

So, Q1 ads guided up 1%. Expectations were 3% or so.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Investment in programming becomes a two-year project rather than a one-year one.

FATDAZ @grouch perhaps BE or PM have seen the full note and can tell us
BE11:19am

Lots of moving parts tho. Here's Barclays.

BE11:19am

Planning guidance for 2018E EBITA leading to a number below consensus (starting at £842m plus £0m / 0% advertising, -£30m programming, -£15m investment, -£5m Encore closure, £15m (good growth in Studio, let’s assume 5%) and £13m growth in online equates to £820m 2018E EBITA). Consensus is at £830m.

red @Flaneurthink its still hard to buy anything of good quality at good money.
red @FATDAZabout as certain as mario draghi being dovish euro.
11:21 am
BE11:21am

.... and before the ROTR gains sentience and starts quoting their own broker research, making us entirely obsolete, here's that UBS comment requested.

erlkin Gold got smoked while volatility reared it's ugly head....when will the shiny yellow be loved again? i thought Powell was great....he's going to cause a huge move in markets.....he is aware of the Bond Market Bubble and is willing to address it.....volatility is back i think in a big way....Chinese are concerned over Debt levels!.....why don't they just go on a gold standard and get it over with.....
BE11:21am

Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: TV NAR in H118 to be positive with Q118 +1% (UBS +0%) (Jan -3%, Feb -2%, Mar +7%, Apr negative) and growth in Q218 around the FWC (UBS +3%). 2018 schedule costs guided at £1055-1060m (UBSe £1060m) and 2019 c£1100m (UBSe £1075m). For Studios, expect good organic growth in 2018, with 60% of budgeted revenue secured. FY18 exceptionals are expected at £85m (UBS £30m), adj. interest £35m (UBS £57m), capex £100m (UBSe £51m), -£35m 2018 FX impact on rev (£5m on profit), with investments of £15-20m in ongoing new property, online and data in 2018.

FATDAZ @BE re add spend saw a UBS note on advertising /WPP in last week that had a very different take about add spending plans
BE11:21am

Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: Positives: pension deficit, studios organic revenue growth. Negatives: higher guidance for programming costs, exceptionals, investments & capex, end to special dividend, higher net debt. Jan-Feb trading weak, March benefits from earlier Easter.

Flaneur @red - read my para again. It might be hard to buy, but its a helluva lot harder to sell - unless youre selling a property to your own pension fund (to release cash) and renting it back from yourself.....
11:21 am
BE11:22am

...... or half of it, at least.

chad_john @BE Verizon!

BE11:25am

Overall, this is likely to lead to less than 1% cut to consensus EBITA in 2018 and c.5% cut in 2019.
ITV announced full-year ordinary dividends of 7.8p with no special dividend (GSe total 10.5p) as the company considers there is now a more normal ordinary dividend, leverage is at 1.0x and the strategy refresh is underway.
At 10X 2019E P/E and 7% dividend yield with M&A optionality, we believe the stock represents attractive risk/reward, hence we retain our Buy rating. Our 12m price target is 198p, based 70% on a P/E value (11X 2019E P/E) and 30% on M&A (10.0X 2019E EBITDA, reflecting previous sector deal multiples). Key risks include macro headwinds, lower ratings and value-destructive M&A.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

So ............ All in all, there's not a lot to say here. Foxtons remains Foxtons. Have Peel Hunt.

BE11:34am

Conditions in the London residential market remain tricky,
particularly in sales. FY17 revenues of c£118m were down 11%
on the prior year, driven mainly by the challenging sales market
with volumes down 26% for the year. Adjusted EBITDA was
down 39% at £15.1m, with the margin down 570 bps to 12.8%.
The shares are now trading on a FY18E PE of c33x, which in our
view is pricing in a near-term recovery. We expect challenging
market conditions to persist for some time and continue to see
downside risks. We make no changes to our target price or
recommendation at this stage. Sell.

wayneJ Was thinking - are leaky drafty houses a hedge against global warming - they leak enough heat to stop the nearby road from freezing?
PM11:34am

(See Flaneur's flaming again)

chad_john Thanks guys
red @Flaneurempty or not, if the demand is there they will keep stacking them. london certainly at risk, but id expect a lot of external demand once sterling repices and brexit out of way.
11:34 am
BE11:34am

And for the opposite opinion, Numis is a buyer again.

BE11:34am

It is worth considering that Foxtons currently has 67 branches in London, which compares to 44 in 2013 when the group made c.£50m of EBITDA. And whilst we would not expect the per branch metrics to return to these high levels, it does give an indication of Foxtons' potential in better market conditions, which are currently close to 2009 lows.

Flaneur @PM ;) - Toasting, Paul, Toasting.
Otter I always enjoy the comments from Mr. the Flaneur
BE11:35am

With no prospect of improving market conditions, we have reduced 2018 forecasts to reflect a lower run-rate in sales and investment in the business. In our view, until the London second-hand sales market improves (where there is no sign currently), Foxtons will only make low levels of profit. However, we gain comfort from the group's strong balance sheet and cash conversion, and therefore when London volumes do improve, the group will be well placed to capitalise on its market leading position in sales and lettings in London, where it now has 85% coverage.

11:35 am

BE11:41am

Taylor Wimpey's FY2017 results were in line with our (and the market's) expectations. FY2018 has started well and we are making no changes to our current estimates. With strong earnings visibility and a yield of more than 7%, we continue to recommend that investors buy Taylor Wimpey's shares.

rw42 But unless lab/cons position as hard or no brexit then a GE is pointless - vote for either party, and maybe get some sort of brexit doesn't sound like the sort of event to bring any sort of clarity to the process :(

BE11:41am

It's not rock'n'roll, but it is built on rock. As we lap the 10th anniversary of the darkest year of the credit crunch, it is good to remember how much of Taylor Wimpey's cash generation and stability we can now take for granted. We view these results as a strong and high-quality canvas on which the group can paint a medium-term vision at its Capital Markets Day in May 2018.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Valuation: At 194p, Taylor Wimpey trades on a CY2018 P/B of 1.73x and offers a yield of 7.2%. Our PT is based on the simple average of a P/B multiple of 1.60x and a PER of 11x applied to our CY2018 estimates plus dividend probability weighted across our Neutral Case (40%), Upside Case (40%) and Downside Case (20%).

BE11:45am

2017 was a challenging year for Travis Perkins (TPK). Volumes
remained broadly unchanged year-on-year. However a
challenging input price environment, a step-up in operating costs, and a disappointing second half for Consumer all resulted in a double-digit decline in underlying full year trading profits. Given the mixed near-term outlook, 2018 performance is expected to be similar to 2017, suggesting that consensus expectations must be reduced by at least 4% (we already forecast flat profits yoy). We reiterate our ‘Underperform’ recommendation.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

And Cazenove.

BE11:46am

2017 results are below our expectations. Adj. EBITA of £380m is 2% below our est. and 1% below co. consensus. That figure is, however, flattered by property profits (£29m vs. guidance and our est. of £20m) – pre-property profits adj. EBITA is 5% below our estimate, largely driven by a weaker Consumer division, where LFL revenue turned negative in Q4 and the H2 margin declined materially. The statement does, however, suggest that, rather than being market driven, this is largely the result of an unsuccessful promotional strategy and cost investment, both of which have been reversed into the new year, with positive effect. On the positive side, LFL growth held up in all other divisions into the end of the year, ahead of our expectations. The group expects overall 2018 performance to be similar to 2017 (implying small growth ex-property profits (guidance: £20m)). We have cut our adj. EBITA est. by 4% to £382m and EPS by 6% to 112.5p.
